Package src.ListADT

Class ResizeableList<T>

java.lang.Object
src.ListADT.ResizeableList<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
ListInterface<T>
public class ResizeableList<T> extends Object implements ListInterface<T>
The ResizeableList class that implements the ListInterface interface. This class implements all the methods from the interface while also adding functionality for doubling the capacity of the list whenever we fill the list up. The index of a ResizeableList object starts at 1. Each method is documented separately.
Version:
1.3
Author:
George Matta, Pierlorenzo Peruzzo

  • Field Details

    • array

      private T[] array
      The pure Java Array that we will be populating

    • numOfEntries

      private int numOfEntries
      A field denoting the number of entries in our array. This number can increase (or decrease) by more than 1 if we add an element to an index that is larger than numOfEntries + 1 More info. on this can be found in the documentations for the add and remove methods.

    • integrityOk

      private boolean integrityOk
      A boolean denoting whether or not the constructor was called properly.

    • MAX_CAPACITY

      private static final int MAX_CAPACITY
      A static final field denoting the maximum capacity of any list.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • DEFAULT_CAPACITY

      private static final int DEFAULT_CAPACITY
      A static final field denoting the default capacity of a list. We use this capacity if one is not provided in the constructor.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

  • Constructor Details

    • ResizeableList

      public ResizeableList()
      The default constructor. Creates a ResizeableList with DEFAULT_CAPACITY capacity by delegating to the ResizeableList(int) constructor

    • ResizeableList

      public ResizeableList(int capacity)
      The main constructor of our ResizeableList. Creates a ResizeableList given a capacity.
      Parameters:
      capacity - The capacity we want the list to have.

    • checkCapacity

      private void checkCapacity(int capacity)
      Throws an error if the capacity of the list is too large or too small.
      Parameters:
      capacity - The capacity we are checking.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the capacity is greater than the maximum or less than 1.

    • ensureCapacity

      private void ensureCapacity(int index)
      Continuously doubles the capacity while a provided index is larger than capacity.
      Parameters:
      index - The index we are checking if it is too large.

    • doubleCapacity

      private void doubleCapacity()
      Doubles the capacity of the array. This method also checks the new capacity with the checkCapacity(int) method, creates an array using createArray(int), and then copies the entries of the old array to the new one using copyEntries(T[]).

    • copyEntries

      private T[] copyEntries(T[] newArray)
      Copies all the entries from this array into a new array
      Parameters:
      newArray - The array to copy the entries into
      Returns:
      The array with the copied entries

    • checkIntegrity

      private void checkIntegrity()
      Checks the integrity of the ResizeableList to make sure the constructor was called.
      Throws:
      SecurityException - if the list object was corrupted in some way or the constructor wasn't run properly.

    • checkIndexInRange

      private void checkIndexInRange(int index)
      Checks if a provided index is within the range of the list [1-numOfEntries]
      Parameters:
      index - The index we are checking.
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is not in the range [1-numOfEntries]

    • add

      public void add(int index, T entry)
      Adds an entry to the list given an index such that arr[index] == entry. Since we are in a list, we want to maintain the order of the elements, so we employ the moveEntriesForward(int) method. We call this method to create a space for us to fit the entry into. We also need to maintain the numOfEntries field, so we increase it (by at least 1). In special cases where the index is larger than the numOfEntries by a factor of more than 1, we increase the number of entries more. The formula to calculate how much we are increasing the numOfEntries field by is index - numOfEntries. So whenever we add an element, we increase the numOfEntries by a factor of Math.max(1, index-numOfEntries).
      Specified by:
      add in interface ListInterface<T>
      Parameters:
      index - The index we want to add the entry to.
      entry - The element we want to add.

    • add

      public void add(T entry)
      Adds an entry to the end of the list.
      Specified by:
      add in interface ListInterface<T>
      Parameters:
      entry - The entry we want to add to the end of the list.

    • remove

      public T remove(int index)
      Removes an element from the list given an index. Similarly to the add method, we use the moveEntriesBack(int) method to maintain the order of the list. Further, we decrease the number of entries by 1, and then continue to decrement the number of entries for each trailing "null" entry in our list. For example: We have a list: [1, 2, null, null, 3] We remove the element "3": [1, 2, null, null] We remove the trailing "null"s: [1, 2]
      Specified by:
      remove in interface ListInterface<T>
      Parameters:
      index - The index of the element we want to remove.
      Returns:
      The removed element.

    • remove

      public T remove()
      Removes the last element from the list.
      Specified by:
      remove in interface ListInterface<T>
      Returns:
      The last element from the list (the removed element).

    • moveEntriesBack

      private T moveEntriesBack(int index)
      Removes an entry from a list by moving all proceeding elements back an index. This method serves to actually remove the element from the list, and it maintains the order of the elements.
      Parameters:
      index - The index of the element we want to remove
      Returns:
      The removed element

    • moveEntriesForward

      private void moveEntriesForward(int index)
      Moves all entries from the index forward once to create a null entry at index This is basically the opposite of moveEntriesBack(int)
      Parameters:
      index - The index of the element we want to make null

    • set

      public T set(int index, T entry)
      Sets an element at a specified index to the entry. This method does not change the number of entries, it simply replaces an element with another element.
      Specified by:

      Parameters:
      index - The index of the element we want to replace.
      entry - The entry we want to replace the element with.
      Returns:
      The element we 'removed' from the list

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      Checks if the list is empty. We do this by checking if the number of entries is 0.
      Specified by:
      isEmpty in interface ListInterface<T>
      Returns:
      true if the list is empty, false if it isn't.

    • isFull

      public boolean isFull()
      Checks if the list is full We do this by checking if the number of entries is greater than or equal to one less than the capacity. (In Java, we can't add an element to index array.length using the native arr[ind])
      Specified by:
      isFull in interface ListInterface<T>
      Returns:
      true if the list is full, false if it isn't

    • clear

      public void clear()
      Clears a list of all its entries. We do this by continuously removing the last entry (by calling remove()) until the list is empty (isEmpty()).
      Specified by:
      clear in interface ListInterface<T>

    • getArray

      public T[] getArray()
      Retrieves the basic generic-type array of the list. This is a simple getter method that returns this.array
      Specified by:
      getArray in interface ListInterface<T>
      Returns:
      A generic-type array of the elements in the list (this.array)

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a readable String representation of a ResizeableList object. The String follows the following format: [a, b, c, ..., d] Capacity: capacity NumEntries: numOfEntries
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      The String representation of the ResizeableList object
